article.title: The ratios between the moments of inertia of triaxial nuclei: Comment on the Physical Review C 95, 064315 (2017)

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares different models for calculating the moments of inertia of a triaxial nucleus. What is the main takeaway regarding the microscopic cranking model results (thin colored lines)?
choices: They closely align with the rigid body values, supporting the assumption in Refs. [1, 3].
They exhibit a strong dependence on the pairing strength, contradicting the irrotational flow model.
They generally follow the irrotational flow values, with the moment of inertia of the short axis systematically larger.
They fluctuate significantly with varying triaxiality parameter, making it difficult to draw definitive conclusions.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure showcases the moments of inertia for three different y intervals (long, medium, short) for Z=68, N=96 and ε=0.25. What do the intersections of the red vertical lines represent?
choices: The moments of inertia for a specific pairing strength.
The transition points between different types of wobbling modes.
The moments of inertia for the three axes when the triaxiality parameter y = 20°.
The critical points where the rigid body and irrotational flow models converge.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure, focusing on Z=38, N=76, and ε=0.2, highlights the differences between model predictions for moments of inertia. Which statement accurately describes the behavior of the rigid body moments of inertia (thick dashed lines) as the triaxiality parameter varies?
choices: They remain relatively similar for all three axes, especially for weakly triaxial and axial nuclei.
They exhibit a strong dependence on the triaxiality parameter, mirroring the trend of the irrotational flow model.
They diverge significantly for the three axes as the triaxiality parameter increases, confirming the findings of Refs. [1, 3].
They show a negligible dependence on the triaxiality parameter, suggesting limitations of the rigid body model.

multiple_choice_question.text: This formula represents the rigid body value for the moment of inertia of a triaxial density distribution. What is the main criticism raised against using this formula in the context of describing wobbling motion in triaxial nuclei?
choices: It assigns the largest moment of inertia to the short axis, contradicting the fundamental property of quantum many-body systems.
It fails to account for the influence of pairing correlations, leading to inaccurate predictions for weakly deformed nuclei.
It relies on the assumption of irrotational flow, which is not always applicable for real nuclei with varying deformation.
It neglects the contribution from the angular momentum of individual nucleons, resulting in an oversimplified representation.
